solution_line_template: One kilogram of tomatoes is {cheaper_percentage} * {cucumber_cost_per_kg} = $<<{cheaper_percentage}*{cucumber_cost_per_kg}={tomato_discount_per_kg}>>{tomato_discount_per_kg} cheaper than one kilogram of cucumbers.
This means that one kilogram of tomatoes costs {cucumber_cost_per_kg} - {tomato_discount_per_kg} = $<<{cucumber_cost_per_kg}-{tomato_discount_per_kg}={tomato_cost_per_kg}>>{tomato_cost_per_kg}.
So two kilograms of tomatoes is a cost of {quantity_tomatoes} * {tomato_cost_per_kg} = $<<{quantity_tomatoes}*{tomato_cost_per_kg}={total_cost_tomatoes}>>{total_cost_tomatoes}.
And three kilograms of cucumbers is a cost of {quantity_cucumbers} * {cucumber_cost_per_kg} = $<<{quantity_cucumbers}*{cucumber_cost_per_kg}={total_cost_cucumbers}>>{total_cost_cucumbers}.
So the price for both products would be {total_cost_tomatoes} + {total_cost_cucumbers} = $<<{total_cost_tomatoes}+{total_cost_cucumbers}={total_price_both_products}>>{total_price_both_products}.
